An account of an Experiment
on Light and Colours, made and communi=
cated in a Letter to S<r> hans Sloane Pr. R.
Society, by Martin Triewald D.M. F.R.S.
Stockholm May 29: 1731.

Tho' no known truth in natural Philosophy
is more evident than the theory of Light & Colours
laid down by Sir Isaac Newton; yet a great
many learned Men in Germany and other parts,
rather love to Stick to come off Notions of their
own, than they would gran the honour of that
surprizing discovery due to that immortal man.

As for my part, I feel a particular delight, the 
oftener I repeat those excellent Experiments, which
have convinced me of such surprizing truths.

T'other day, viz. the 25<th> of May, being a 
very clear day, I try'd over all the experiments
relating to Light and Colours: and coming to
those which prove that the Rays of Light suffer
not any change of their qualities from refraction; 
and that all those original Colours which appear
as soon as the Rays of Light pass thro' the Prism,
and are refracted by the same, will again produce
white, when collected by a convex Lens.  I say, whilst 
I was about those experiments, it came into my mind
to try whether a white Spectrum could be produced in
case these coloured Rays fell on a concave Speculum,
and should by the same be diverged to a certain
degree and distance.
